image.altText: Jim Chalmers stands in a courtyard at parliament house.

props.synopsis: The federal government has released its Employment White Paper after a year-long consultation that will pave the way for future jobs and skills in Australia, while the ASX has opened lower after Wall Street fell on Friday. Follow live.

title.children: 'Very important day' as government releases Employment White Paper, Qantas to spend $80m on customer 'pain points', ASX lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As part of the Employment White Paper, there are nine steps the federal government is going to take to prepare the economy for the future. These nine steps are: Progress scoping work on a National Skills Passport in consultation with employers, unions, the tertiary education sector and governments, to help workers demonstrate and promote their qualifications and businesses to find more skilled workers. Turbocharge TAFE Centres of Excellence with up to six to begin developing courses in 2024, working with the states and territories and education providers to design world-leading skills and curriculum. Accelerate the take up of higher apprenticeships in the priority areas of net zero, care, and digitalisation. Permanently extend the Work Bonus measure for older pensioners and eligible veterans, giving them the option to earn more income from working without reducing their pension. Smooth the transition to work for many income support recipients by doubling the period they can receive a nil rate of payment, allowing them to retain access to social security benefits such as concession cards for longer when they first get back into work. Address labour market data gaps to support policy development and program delivery. Back social enterprises to address persistent labour market disadvantage, focusing on the role they could play in employment services and in creating jobs and career pathways. Reform the Local Jobs Program to improve its flexibility and provide practical initiatives and action to better help jobseekers Collaborate with the Coalition of Peaks and First Nations stakeholders to scope an economic partnership.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal government to take 'nine immediate steps' to boost jobs and opportunities

children.content: As part of the Employment White Paper, there are nine steps the federal government is going to take to prepare the economy for the future.
These nine steps are:

Progress scoping work on a National Skills Passport in consultation with employers, unions, the tertiary education sector and governments, to help workers demonstrate and promote their qualifications and businesses to find more skilled workers.

Turbocharge TAFE Centres of Excellence with up to six to begin developing courses in 2024, working with the states and territories and education providers to design world-leading skills and curriculum.
Accelerate the take up of higher apprenticeships in the priority areas of net zero, care, and digitalisation.
Permanently extend the Work Bonus measure for older pensioners and eligible veterans, giving them the option to earn more income from working without reducing their pension.

Smooth the transition to work for many income support recipients by doubling the period they can receive a nil rate of payment, allowing them to retain access to social security benefits such as concession cards for longer when they first get back into work.
Address labour market data gaps to support policy development and program delivery.
Back social enterprises to address persistent labour market disadvantage, focusing on the role they could play in employment services and in creating jobs and career pathways.
Reform the Local Jobs Program to improve its flexibility and provide practical initiatives and action to better help jobseekers
Collaborate with the Coalition of Peaks and First Nations stakeholders to scope an economic partnership.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government wants to redefine how employment is measured across the country, as it plans for the jobs the Australian economy will need in the future. Releasing its Employment White Paper today, one of the issues raised by the government is the way the nation considers the idea of "full employment". The paper argues there's too much of a focus on people simply being employed when developing policy and monitoring the state of the labour market. Instead it argues there needs to be a greater emphasis on whether their full range of skills are being utilised, and whether people are working as many hours as they actually want. The government will invest tens of millions of dollars in TAFE courses across the country and permanently extend the ability for some pensioners and veterans to work and earn income without seeing their pensions reduce. You can read more on this from my colleague, business reporter Gareth Hutchens, below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal government to redefine how employment is measured

featuredLink.title: The federal government will redefine 'full employment' to reflect a modern labour market, the Employment White Paper has found

children.content: The federal government wants to
redefine how employment is measured across the country
, as it plans for the jobs the Australian economy will need in the future.
Releasing its Employment White Paper today, one of the issues raised by the government is the way the nation considers the idea of "full employment".
The paper argues there's
too much of a focus on people simply being employed
when developing policy and monitoring the state of the labour market.
Instead it argues there needs to be a greater emphasis on whether their full range of skills are being utilised, and whether people are working as many hours as they actually want.
The government will invest
tens of millions of dollars in TAFE courses across the country
and permanently extend the ability for
some pensioners and veterans to work and earn income
without seeing their pensions reduce
You can read more on this from my colleague,
business reporter Gareth Hutchens
, below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is about to officially release the Employment White Paper at a press conference. He'll be joined by Minister for Skills and Training Brendan O'Connor, Minister for Education Jason Clare, Minister for Social Services Amanda Rishworth, Minister for Home Affairs Clare O'Neil and Minister for Indigenous Australians Linda Burney. You can tune into the full press conference below, or at the top of the blog: (I'll also be bringing you the latest developments from the press conference right here on the blog.)
